 Hi everyone, I'm Noa Weiss and today I'll be talking about the unspoken problems with
machine learning and security. I'd like to thank all of you for joining me and also to
thank Ziskon for having me. It's a great honor to be talking on the conference. Hopefully
next year we'll be able to do this offline. So let's get started. So a little about me,
I'm an AI and machine learning consultant. I've been playing with data for over a decade,
both in the industry and academia. I've mostly worked in the risk and cybersecurity domains,
which I'm very fond of, and starting PayPal. Then I worked as a consultant for startups
to help them manage their risk. And lately I work for Armins, for those of you who've
heard of it. I also, in my spare time, I'm a research engineer in the Deep Voice Foundation,
where we try to utilize deep learning technique to improve whale research around the world
in order to protect and preserve the whale population. I'm also the leader of the Israeli
community of women in data science, and I mentor junior data scientists taking their
first steps in the field. And last but not least, I'm the proud owner or proud human
of those two adorable cats. Say hi. And let's get to it. So the agenda for today. First,
since I'm claiming that we do have unspoken problems in machine learning and security,
then I'll try to demonstrate that claim. We'll talk about whether the grass really is greener.
We'll do that by looking at machine learning at other domains, where they're at, and then
where we are at security. Then we'll talk about the things that hold us back. What are
the causes for machine learning and security not being in the same level as some of the
other domains that utilize machine learning? And then about possible solutions, things
that I think we can do to change this. So if we split it up to three parts, we basically

It does make a mistake there, though. And the human asks, does this code return just the even numbers? Or does it remove all the even numbers? The AI says it returns just the even numbers. In security, specifically to identify risky activity, transactions, etc.

anomaly detection algorithms are not ideal for security for a few reasons.

False positive means that the algorithm identified something as an anomaly,

when that wasn't actually the case.

when we're talking about security
